Dear Ms. Ritchie:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 269-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
Description supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
checks of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation For the past three months, three staff members have been
sleeping on the couch during their night shifts. There are three
youth with cognitive impairments and developmental disabilities
that are at risk when not being supervised. They have not been
harmed at this time. 15-minute checks are required and are not
being completed. On 1/25/24, the back door to the facility was left
open from 8:15 pm-2:00 am.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant/Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 2/13/24.
Staff 1 reported she no longer works at the facility but talks to staff
who work there still. Staff 1 reported the staff call her to share their
concerns because nothing is being done about their concerns at
the facility. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 called to tell her Staff 5, Staff 3
and Staff 4 were sleeping on shift. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 told her
she has reported this information to Administrator/LD, but nothing
is being done to fix the issue. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 works third
shift, typically with Staff 5. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 told her Staff 2
is normally upstairs while Staff 5 is downstairs. Staff 1 reported
Staff 2 told her when she comes downstairs, Staff 5 is sleeping,
and Staff 2 has been doing bed checks for all the kids because
he’s not. Staff 1 reported she lives right behind the facility and on
1/24/24, she saw the back door to the facility was open from
around 8pm that night until approximately 2am on 1/25/24. Staff 1
reported she felt it was a safety concern for the door to be open
the entire time without staff taking care of it.
Youth B is not verbal and could not be interviewed. Youth B
was seen in the home on 2/13/24 and there were no concerns
noted.
Youth A and Youth C were interviewed face to face separately
on 2/15/24 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Youth A and
2

Youth C reported they have never seen staff sleeping in the house
and staff are always awake.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone by MDHHS Worker on
2/9/24 and by this Consultant on 2/14/24. Staff 2 reported she
has never said she has seen Staff 5 sleeping on shift because
when they work together, she works upstairs and he’s downstairs.
Staff 2 reported she doesn’t work with Staff 4 and, therefore, has
never seen him sleeping. Staff 2 reported she worked with Staff 3
one time, but never saw him sleeping. Staff 2 reported she was
doing laundry one night and Staff 3 wasn’t in the living room, so
she assumed Staff 3 must be in the sensory room sleeping. Staff
2 reported she has never seen any staff sleeping in the house
when they’re supposed to be working. Staff 2 reported Staff 3,
Staff 4 and Staff 5 do not complete bed checks for the youth in the
home, and she is the only one completing them. Staff 2 reported
she has told Administrator 2/Licensee Designee (LD) about this
concern, and nothing is being done. Staff 2 was unable to provide
dates or timeframes for when these conversations occurred.
However, Staff 2 reported she would send screenshots of the text
messages she sent to Administrator/LD regarding her concerns.
Staff 2 initially reported she wasn’t working on 1/24/24, the night
the door was left open, so she doesn’t know anything about it.
However, when informed she was seen on video exiting the door
prior to it being left open, she changed her story. Staff 2 reported
she walked out of the door first and then Staff 7 walked out after
her. Staff 2 reported she assumed Staff 7 left the door open
because Staff 7 had a lot of stuff in her hands. When asked why
she didn’t check if the door was shut or ask Staff 7 if she shut the
door, Staff 2 reported she was not thinking about the door being
open or shut. Staff 2 reported if the door was left open, third shift
staff should have caught it if they were doing their observation
checks and laundry on shift like they’re supposed to. Staff 2
reported there’s no policy to check the outside doors and make
sure they’re locked.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on 2/21/24 in conjunction
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3 reported he picks up various shifts
at the facility, and most recently worked separate shifts with Staff
4 and Staff 2. Staff 3 reported when he works with someone, one
staff is upstairs and one staff is downstairs, so they do not have a
lot of contact with each other. Staff 3 reported he hasn’t seen any
staff sleeping on shift, and he has never slept on shift.
3

Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/15/24
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Staff 4 reported he works
third shift, and either works alone or with whoever picks up the
shift with him. Staff 4 reported he worked the overnight shift
1/24/24-1/25/24. Staff 4 reported after midnight, Staff 6 went to get
his charger and found the back door open. Staff 4 reported there
is a door alarm that chimes when the door is open and the
security system says, “back door open”, so they knew no one had
come in during their shift. Staff 4 reported they didn’t know how
the door was left open, or how long it was left open. Staff 4
reported the basement door is locked and he and Staff 6 were in
the living room most of the time, so they knew no one had come
into the house and gone in the basement or upstairs. Staff 4
reported he did not hear Staff 7 ask him or Staff 6 to shut the door
when she was leaving. Staff 4 reported there have never been
times when he has fully fallen asleep during a shift, but he has
dozed off a few times. Staff 4 admitted he hasn’t always done bed
checks every 15 minutes or less, even though he knows that’s the
requirement.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/15/24
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Staff 5 reported he always
works third shift on the main level of the home while Staff 2 works
upstairs. Staff 5 reported he knows he’s not supposed to sleep on
shift, but admitted he has fallen asleep a few times. Staff 5
reported he has a full-time job outside of the facility, children of his
own and the children’s activities, so he doesn’t get a lot of sleep.
Staff 6 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/15/24
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Staff 6 reported he worked
the overnight shift 1/24/24-1/25/24. Staff 6 reported after midnight,
he went outside to grab his phone charger from his car, and
noticed the back door was open. Staff 6 reported he looked down
to the basement because he didn’t know why the door was open
or if someone had come in. Staff 6 reported when he came back
inside, he talked to Staff 4, who also didn’t know the back door
was open. Staff 6 was unsure how long the door had been open.
Staff 6 reported he did not hear Staff 7 ask him or Staff 4 to shut
the door when she was leaving. Staff 6 reported he has dozed off
and woken right back up while working third shift before but has
never fully fallen asleep. Staff 6 reported he knows he is not
supposed to sleep on shift.
Staff 7 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/15/24
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Staff 7 worked until 8pm
on 1/24/24. Staff 7 reported she had a lot of stuff in her hands
4

when she was exiting the back door of the facility at the end of her
shift and was unable to shut the door. Staff 7 reported when she
left the facility, Staff 2 was already gone. Staff 7 reported as she
was walking to the door, she yelled out “could you please close
the door for me?” Staff 7 reported she was intending to yell to
Staff 4 and Staff 6, but she didn’t say their names. Staff 7 reported
she thought she yelled loud enough for them to hear, so she
assumed they would do it, and left to go home. Staff 7 admitted
she didn’t hear them reply or confirm they would shut the door.
Administrator 1 was interviewed via phone on 2/9/24 and
2/14/24, and face to face at the facility on 2/13/24 and 2/15/24
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Administrator 1 reported
she, Previous Chief Administrator, and Administrator 2/LD were
regularly checking cameras on third shift to ensure staff were
completing checks as required. However, they haven’t been
checking cameras regularly since there have been changes in the
leadership team. Administrator 1 reported after she received the
allegations, she reviewed camera footage and found Staff 5
sleeping on shift. Administrator 1 reported she found Staff 3, Staff
4, and Staff 5 were not completing bed checks as required during
various shifts. Administrator 1 reported she spoke with Staff 4,
who reported he was doing checks at first, but the kids were
always fine, so he didn’t see the point in doing them anymore.
Administrator 1 reported since she had the conversation with Staff
4 the weekend of 2/10-2/11/24, he has been doing the checks
consistently. Administrator 1 reported she watched camera
footage the entire weekend and was messaging/calling staff if they
were not completing checks as required. For example,
Administrator 1 reported she saw on live-camera, Staff 2 was
missing bed checks or was not doing them in variable intervals, so
she was messaging Staff 2 to tell her it was time for a check or
providing directions for how to complete the checks. Administrator
1 reported she spoke with Staff 5 regarding bed checks, and Staff
5 completed every bed check required that weekend.
Administrator 1 reported she also spoke with Staff 6 about bed
checks, and he is also making immediate changes based on the
feedback received. Administrator 1 reported Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff
4, Staff 5, and Staff 6 are all receiving write-ups for not completing
bed checks as required.
Administrator 2/LD was interviewed face to face at the facility
on 2/13/24 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Administrator
2/LD reported Staff 2 called her and reported Staff 5 doesn’t do
anything to help with any tasks during their shifts, but never stated
Staff 5 was not completing bed checks or was sleeping on shift.
5

Administrator 2/LD reported she offered to hold a meeting with
Staff 2 and Staff 5 to resolve the issues, but Staff 2 refused
because she didn’t want to meet with Staff 5. Administrator 2/LD
reported Staff 2 has never told her Staff 3 and Staff 4 were
sleeping during their shifts. Administrator 2/LD reported Staff 2
does not work with Staff 3 or Staff 4, so she’s not sure how Staff 2
would know such information.
Administrator 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
2/13/24 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Administrator 3
reported they try to schedule two people on third shift as much as
possible, but their ratio only requires one person on shift.
Administrator 3 reported Staff 2 and Staff 5 work the same shifts,
with Staff 2 primarily working upstairs and Staff 5 primarily working
downstairs. Administrator 3 reported Staff 3 has worked
approximately 1 shift since October 2023 as he was on contingent
status due to a medical issue. Administrator 3 reported Staff 4 is
single-staffed on third shift until 5 am, and then various staff
members volunteer to fill in as a second staff member on shift for
a few hours from 5-8am to assist with getting the youth ready for
school. Administrator 3 reported Staff 4 and Staff 6 worked the
overnight shift between 1/24/24-1/25/24, when the door was left
open.
ON-SITE FACILITY WALKTHROUGH:
A walkthrough of the facility occurred on 2/13/24. The back door of
the facility leading outside is a down a flight a stair at the end of
the hallway past the kitchen. The back door cannot be seen when
completing a bed check for the main floor bedroom. The only way
staff would be able to see the backdoor was open is if they were
going out the backdoor or going down to the basement.
VIDEO FOOTAGE REVIEWED:
• Video footage for the overnight shift of 1/24/24-1/25/24 was
reviewed.
o The back door was open from approximately
8:10pm-12:26am. The door was left open by Staff 7
when she was leaving at the end of her shift. At
12:26am, Staff 6 went down the stairs, saw the back
door open, looked towards the basement, and went
outside. At 12:27am, Staff 6 came back inside,
closed the door behind him, and checked to make
sure it was closed.
o No bed check was completed for Youth B between
8:10-8:34pm, but then one was completed.
Throughout the rest of the video, Staff 4 and Staff 6
6

did not complete bed checks as frequently as
required throughout the night, but the staff were not
asleep.
• Video footage of 2/4/24 was reviewed and Staff 5 was
found to be sleeping on the couch on the main floor of the
facility. Bed checks were not completed as required.
• Multiple videos of 2/6/24 were reviewed. From 3:17am-
3:32am, Staff 4 was on the main level sitting on the couch
in the living room with his head resting on his hand or
laying on his arm. It is unclear if he was sleeping. Staff 4
did not complete any bed checks. From 3:10am-4:45am,
Staff 4 was in the Sunroom on his phone and did not
complete any bed checks.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Bed Check logs from 12/11/23-2/11/24 were reviewed.
There were many checks exceeding 15 minutes. In
addition, there were many times checks were completed
every 15 minutes in consecutive intervals, rather than at
variable intervals. For example:
o On 12/11/23, Staff 2 completed 54 checks. Out of
those 54 checks, 2 checks exceeded 15 minutes
(one was 25 minutes, and another was 18 minutes)
and 42 checks were completed at 15-minute
intervals exactly.
o On 12/15/23, Staff 4 completed 44 checks. Out of
those 44 checks, 29 checks exceeded 15 minutes
(anywhere from 16 minutes-25 minutes).
o On 1/10/24, Staff 9 completed all checks at 15
minutes exactly from 8:15pm-7am.
o On 1/13/24, Staff 2 completed 49 checks. Out of
those 49 checks, 3 checks exceeded 15 minutes (17
minutes, 27 minutes & 28 minutes) and 26 checks
were completed at 15 minutes exactly.
• LTAI Supervision Policy (rev. 2/2023) states during
sleeping hours, employees should complete bedroom
checks in every room, ensuring eyes are on each youth at
variable times and not exceeding 15 minutes between each
bed check.
• Reviewed screenshots of text messages received from
Staff 2 regarding her conversations with Administrator 2/LD
dated 1/24/24 and 1/28/24. None of the text messages from
7

Staff 2 state Staff 5 is not completing bed checks as
required or sleeping on shift.
• Staff 2’s has 3 disciplinary records in her employee file, but
only one is related to this investigation. Disciplinary Action
for Staff 2 dated 2/28/24 stating Staff 2 was terminated on
2/28/24 due to disclosing the health information of one of
LTAI’s youth to a person outside of the LTAI organization,
which violates HIPAA & the Code of Ethics policy. Staff 2
was trained on the Supervision policy on 10/25/22 and bed
checks on 11/2/22 during orientation. Staff 2 attended a
staff meeting on 5/8/23 where she was re-trained on the
Supervision Policy and bed check procedures.
• Staff 3 has two disciplinary records in his employee file,
unrelated to this investigation. Staff 3 was trained on the
Supervision policy on 12/1/22 and bed checks on 12/5/22
during orientation. Staff 3 attended a staff meeting on
5/8/23 where he was re-trained on the Supervision Policy
and bed check procedures.
• Staff 4 does not have any disciplinary records in his
employee file. Staff 4 was trained on the Supervision policy
on 11/30/23 and bed checks on 12/5/23 during orientation.
• Staff 5 has two disciplinary records in his employee file,
with one being relevant to this investigation. On 7/31/23,
Staff 5 received a written warning for bed checks not being
performed timely on 7/1/23 (as well as additional unrelated
issues). It notes the expected improvement was to be bed
checks being performed at least every 12 minutes or so
during sleeping hours, not to exceed 15 minutes, and a bed
check form is to be completed by the reporting staff. It
notes reassessment was to occur within 30 days and
continued issues in relation to the noted areas will lead to
possible termination. Staff 5 was trained on the Supervision
policy on 8/23/22 and bed checks on 8/24/22 during
orientation Staff 5 attended a staff meeting on 5/8/23 where
he was re-trained on the Supervision Policy and bed check
procedures.
• Staff 6 does not have any disciplinary records in his
employee file. Staff 6 was trained on the Supervision policy
on 2/28/23 and bed checks on 3/6/23 during orientation.
Staff 6 attended a staff meeting on 5/8/23 where he was re-
8

trained on the Supervision Policy and bed check
procedures.
• Staff 9 does not have any disciplinary records in his
employee file. Staff 9 was trained on the Supervision policy
on 10/10/22 and bed checks on 10/12/22 during orientation.
Staff 9 attended a staff meeting on 5/8/23 where he was re-
trained on the Supervision Policy and bed check
procedures.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted, video footage reviewed, and
documentation reviewed, this violation is established. Staff 2, Staff
3, Staff 4, Staff 5, Staff 6, and Staff 9 did not complete bed checks
as required by the facility’s policy and the rule. There is no
violation regarding the door being left open as there is not a facility
policy requiring staff to check outside doors.
CONSULTATION:
- Facility should consider adding a requirement for staff to
check to ensure outside doors are not left open OR adding
a door alarm/chime/notification for when the door is closed
(like the one that chimes/notifies when door opens).
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & ACT 116 - 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination
Section of conditions, books, records, and reports; access by
Description department, bureau of fire services, or local authorities;
records; reports report; forms; confidentiality; disclosure of
information; availability of confidential records; child
information cards to be provided to department; failure of
licensee to cooperation with investigation, inspection, or
examination.
(1) The department may investigate, inspect, and examine
conditions of a childcare organization and may investigate
and examine the books and records of the licensee. The
licensee shall cooperate with the department’s
investigation, inspection, and examination by doing all of
the following:
(c) Providing accurate and truthful information to the
department, and encouraging witnesses, such as staff
and household members, to provide accurate and
truthful information to the department.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Documentation is falsified to reflect the observation checks are
occurring.
9

Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 2/14/24. Staff 2 reported
she has been doing the observation bed checks and physically
writing them down like she’s supposed to, but she can’t speak for
others. Staff 2 reported she assumes they aren’t being done
because she hasn’t seen them. Staff 2 reported when she works
with Staff 5, she isn’t sure if Staff 5 is doing his checks or where
he's documenting them, because they’re not on the same form
she’s writing on. Staff 2 reported at a staff meeting on 2/13/24,
they were told bed checks weren’t being done, documentation
was missing, or the checks weren’t being documented correctly,
so she knows it’s an issue.
Staff 4 and Staff 5 were interviewed separately face to face at
the facility on 2/15/24 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on 2/21/24 in conjunction
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3, Staff 4, and Staff 5 admitted there
have been situations in which they have documented they have
done bed checks at times they haven’t completed them.
Staff 6 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/15/24
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Staff 6 reported he
normally doesn’t work third shift, so he takes Staff 4’s lead on bed
checks and Staff 4 fills out the bed check log sheet.
VIDEO FOOTAGE REVIEWED:
• Multiple videos of 2/6/24 were reviewed. From 3:17am-
3:32am, Staff 4 was in the living room sitting on the couch
and did not complete any bed checks. From 3:10am-
4:45am, Staff 4 was in the Sunroom on his phone and did
not complete any bed checks.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Bed check log from 2/6/24 was reviewed. Log notes a bed
check was completed at 3:21 am, but according to video
footage, Staff 3 nor Staff 4 completed a bed check. Staff 4
signed his initials on the log under the times documented.
• LTAI Supervision Policy (rev. 2/2023) states employees are
responsible for documenting the completion of their bed
checks.
• LTAI Code of Ethics (rev. 3/2023) states employees shall
be honest and truthful in their documentation, reporting,
communicating with their supervisor, coworker, or other
management employees within the organization.
10

• Staff 3 has two disciplinary records in his employee file,
unrelated to this investigation. Staff 3 signed a written
acknowledgment he received and reviewed the LTAI Code
of Ethics on 12/1/22.
• Staff 4 does not have any disciplinary records in his
employee file. Staff 4 signed a written acknowledgment he
received, reviewed, and would abide by the LTAI Code of
Ethics on 11/30/23.
• Staff 5 has two disciplinary records in his employee file as
noted above, with one being relevant to this investigation.
Staff 5 signed a written acknowledgment he received and
reviewed the LTAI Code of Ethics on 8/23/22 and 10/10/22.
Staff 5 also attended a staff meeting on 8/14/23 where the
Code of Ethics was reviewed.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted, video footage reviewed, and
documentation reviewed, this violation is established. Staff 3, Staff
4, and Staff 5 admitted to falsifying documentation regarding bed
checks for youth.
CONSULTATION:
- If there are two staff working and both are completing bed
checks, they should both be completing the bed check log
to ensure accuracy in their respective documentation.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4130 Privacy and confidentiality
Section (1) An institution shall assure resident and parent privacy and
Description confidentiality and shall protect residents from exploitation.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff 2 disclosed confidential information about a youth to
someone who does not work for the facility.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant/Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 2/13/24.
Staff 1 reported Staff 2 told her Youth B has been sick for 2 weeks
and the facility isn’t taking care of his illness or taking him to the
doctor.
Youth B is not verbal and could not be interviewed. Youth B
was seen in the home on 2/13/24 and there were no concerns
noted.
11

Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 2/14/24. Staff 2 reported
she spoke with Staff 1 about Youth B being sick because he was
sick for two weeks (i.e. runny nose, throwing up on and off, etc.).
and nothing was being done about it. Staff 2 reported she stated
she brought these concerns to Staff 1 because she was frustrated,
and Staff 1 is her friend even though Staff 1 doesn’t work at the
facility any longer. Staff 2 reported she felt it was child neglect but
didn’t make a complaint to Centralized Intake because she just felt
it was neglectful two days ago. Staff 2 reported she received a call
from MDHHS Worker last week, so since MDHHS was already
involved, she didn’t feel reporting to Centralized Intake was
necessary. Staff 2 reported Staff 8 also called Staff 1 crying and
complaining about the facility not taking care of Youth B’s
sickness. Staff 2 reported she didn’t know the facility’s policy
regarding confidentiality for youth but was aware of HIPAA
guidelines. Staff 2 reported she had text messages with
Administrator 2/LD complaining about Youth B being sick and the
need for him to go to the doctor, and she would send those.
Staff 8 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/15/24
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Staff 8 reported she is
Staff 1’s Godmother and has been friends with Staff 1’s mother for
37 years. Staff 8 reported she has not been keeping in contact
with Staff 1 since Staff 1 was terminated from employment. Staff 8
reported Staff 1 is upset, and Staff 8 thought she would get over
her anger, but it’s clear she hasn’t. Staff 8 reported she has never
talked to anyone outside of the organization about any of the
youth in care. Staff 8 reported she never called Staff 1 and cried to
her about Youth B’s sickness. Staff 8 reported she has not
complained to anyone about Youth B not being taken care of
properly and hasn’t had any concerns about Youth B not being
taken care of properly. Staff 8 reported Staff 2 and Staff 1 are
friends and Staff 2 is telling Staff 1 about everything happening at
the facility.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
2/13/24 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker and via phone on
2/14/24. Administrator 1 reported there is a weekly round table for
staff and administrators. It is a time for staff to express concerns
they have regarding youth, policy, process, updates on anything in
the home, and good things happening in the facility. Administrator
1 reported if there was a concern with the care of a youth, health
of a youth, etc. it can be reported during that time. Administrator 1
reported Staff 2 has never reported Youth B’s illness to be a
concern. Administrator 1 reported Youth B has not been feeling
well and they’ve been watching his symptoms, and he hasn’t had
12

a fever. This morning, he had more congestion, his cheeks were
red, and his nose was running. Administrator 1 reported staff took
Youth B to the doctor on 2/13/24 at 9:50am and he received an
antibiotic. Administrator 1 was very concerned about Staff 2
violating Youth B’s HIPAA information.
Administrator 2/LD was interviewed face to face at the facility
on 2/13/24 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Administrator 2
reported she had not received any text messages or calls from
Staff 2 complaining about Youth B’s illness or it not being taken
care of properly.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Staff 2 never sent any documentation of the text messages
she reported she sent to Administrator 2/LD about Youth
B’s illness.
• LTAI Privacy and Confidentiality Policy (rev. 4/5/21) states
employees are prohibited from discussing a client’s case
information without provisions for relative confidentiality;
leaving persons’ served case record information on desks,
or in any other unsecured manner, thus violating persons’
served confidentiality; intentionally or unintentionally
mismanaging the resources of the organization or other
stakeholders.
• LTAI Code of Ethics (rev. 3/2023) states the same
information as the Privacy policy above. In addition, the
Code of Ethics states employees shall not divulge
confidential material or information to unauthorized persons
and employees shall protect the confidentiality of persons
served written, verbal, and electronic records and other
sensitive information.
• LTAI Recipient Rights Policy (eff. 11/29/22) states youth
residents have the right to privacy, including the
confidentiality of their personal and medical information.
Information sharing will only occur as permitted by law and
is necessary for their care and protection.
• Staff 2’s has 3 disciplinary records in her employee file, but
only one is related to this investigation. Disciplinary Action
for Staff 2 dated 2/28/24 stating Staff 2 was terminated on
2/28/24 due to disclosing the health information of one of
LTAI’s youth to a person outside of the LTAI organization,
which violates HIPAA & the Code of Ethics policy. Staff 2
13

was trained on the Code of Ethics Policy, which includes
privacy and confidentiality, and the Recipient Rights policy
during orientation on 10/25/22. Staff 2 signed a written
acknowledgment she received and reviewed the LTAI Code
of Ethics on 10/25/22. Staff 2 also attended a staff meeting
